mentions.context: APID, which unifies data from five of the largest PPI databases (Alonso-López et al., 2016;Alonso-López et al., 2019), implements an integration method that takes redundancy into account and enables to distinguish 'experimental evidences' (i.e experimental observations reported in publications) from 'curation events' (i.e.
In MITAB25 formated data, each line represents a curation event.
The JENA suite was used to run the SPARQL queries.
The GenOuest platform provided computational support and Web hosting.
A Perl script was used to connect to this database, to exclude curation events that are not considered by APID (see below), and to convert it into a RDF dataset following the BioPAX v3 standard.
The downloaded MITAB files contain 700, 484 curation events for Homo sapiens and 305, 102 for Saccharomyces cerevisiae (hereinafter referred to as human and yeast, respectively).
In the raw data of APID that aggregates BioGRID, IntAct, HPRD, BioPlex and DIP, we were able to identify both explicit and implicit redundancies.
Queries were run using SPARQL Protocol and RDF Query Language (SPARQL).
For meta-databases such as APID, populated by aggregating curation events from other databases, an entry can be defined by a quintuplet
In its integration process, the APID meta-database does not consider curation events annotated with IDMs that do not correspond to a specific experimental method (Alonso-López et al., 2019).
Raw PPI curation events from the MITAB file were first imported into a MySQL database.

PPI curation events integrated by APID were downloaded from the APID website on March 23, 2020, last update of APID in January, 2019) for two species (Homo sapiens and Saccharomyces cerevisiae) in the MITAB25 format (Kerrien et al., 2007).
The JENA suite was used to run the SPARQL queries.
Thanks to the expressiveness of the SPARQL language, we identified both explicit and implicit redundancies among curation events (example query in Figure 3).
As an example, Figure 3 presents the SPARQL query used to detect implicit redundancies in curation events, if one term is an ancestor of the other in the PSI-MI ontology.
To be able to compare our results with APID, we also excluded from our analysis the very same curation events.
We analysed the same curation events as the APID database to assess the efficiency of redundancy detection methods.
Explicit redundancies are detected and unified by APID and other metadatabases.
Queries were run using SPARQL Protocol and RDF Query Language (SPARQL).

PPI curation events integrated by APID were downloaded from the APID website on March 23, 2020, last update of APID in January, 2019) for two species (Homo sapiens and Saccharomyces cerevisiae) in the MITAB25 format (Kerrien et al., 2007).
Raw PPI curation events from the MITAB file were first imported into a MySQL database.

Some of these meta-databases, such as the Agile Protein Interactomes DataServer (APID) (Alonso-López et al., 2016;Alonso-López et al., 2019), HINT (Das and Yu, 2012) or mentha (Calderone et al., 2013), focus exclusively on experimentally determined PPIs, while others, such as IID (Kotlyar et al., 2019) or STRING (Szklarczyk et al., 2019) also integrate predicted interactions, text mining results or other information.
A Perl script was used to connect to this database, to exclude curation events that are not considered by APID (see below), and to convert it into a RDF dataset following the BioPAX v3 standard.

PPI curation events integrated by APID were downloaded from the APID website on March 23, 2020, last update of APID in January, 2019) for two species (Homo sapiens and Saccharomyces cerevisiae) in the MITAB25 format (Kerrien et al., 2007).
The resulting interaction data were merged with the PSI-MI ontology, available as an OWL file, into a triplestore powered by the Apache Foundation's JENA suite (v3.14.0).

PPI curation events integrated by APID were downloaded from the APID website on March 23, 2020, last update of APID in January, 2019) for two species (Homo sapiens and Saccharomyces cerevisiae) in the MITAB25 format (Kerrien et al., 2007).

Some information such as the direction of the interaction (which protein was used as a 'bait' and which as a 'prey') is not available in this format, but it is usually recorded in primary databases or in more recent MITAB formats (MITAB27).

Some information such as the direction of the interaction (which protein was used as a 'bait' and which as a 'prey') is not available in this format, but it is usually recorded in primary databases or in more recent MITAB formats (MITAB27).
